properties.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 8 at 12:34PM CST by NWS Chicago IL
properties.description:
Rainfall is expected over portions of the Mississippi
Valley, Midwest, and Great Lakes Regions beginning Thursday and
continuing into the weekend. The potential for heavy rainfall
across portions of northeastern Illinois and northwestern Indiana
is currently expected Friday into Saturday. Based upon current
rainfall forecasts, significant flooding is possible in the
Kankakee and Iroquois River Basins.

Soil moisture in some portions of the upper Midwest and Great
Lakes remains very high for early January. Soil moisture quickly
increases from near average in eastern Illinois and central
Indiana to the 99th percentile in northern Illinois. River levels
also range from near average to much above average in these same
regions. No snow cover or frozen soils currently exist across the
area due to the lack of significant cold and snowfall in recent
weeks. Based upon these antecedent conditions, the most
vulnerable areas to heavy rainfall are southern Wisconsin and
northern Illinois, including the Rock, Fox, and Des Plaines River
Basins. Further to the south, including the Kankakee and Iroquois
River Basins, more rainfall would be required to cause flooding.

By Sunday morning, storm total rainfall of at least one inch will
be likely across most of northeastern Illinois and northwestern
Indiana. Some areas may receive up to three inches with locally
higher amounts. If this rainfall occurs, widespread river flooding
would occur as well as flooding of other low-lying and poor
drainage areas. Although uncertainty remains regarding the exact
location and amounts of rainfall, the heaviest rainfall is
currently expected to remain to the south of the most vulnerable
river basins. Even with drier soils and lack of snow cover,
forecasted rainfall has the potential cause significant flooding. The
track of this storm system will be monitored closely as
minor adjustments to the north or south could cause drastic
changes to potential flooding extent and severity.

This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential
impacts are possible. Persons should closely monitor forecasts
including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and
advisories.

NWSheadline: Heavy rainfall late this week may lead to flooding
